awd_titl_txt: URoL:  Epigenetics 2- Collaborative Research: Revealing how epigenetic inheritance governs the environmental challenge response with transformative 3D genomics and machine learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This project seeks to define how plants respond to environmental challenge. Understanding plant responses to environmental stress is important to secure our future national interest in maintaining agricultural productivity and preserving the environment. This project will advance the understanding of how elevated carbon dioxide alters plant form on both the molecular scale of DNA organization, as well on the scale of plant growth. This proposal asks whether these plant responses will last generations, and if so, tests the mechanism of inheritance. Additionally, this project promotes the training and development of a diverse future science-enabled workforce. The product of this research will be a predictive model for the lasting consequences of environmental challenge on growth patterns across the plant kingdom.

It is unclear how environmental challenge broadly alters plant form, and whether the resulting changes are inherited epigenetically to the subsequent generations. This proposal establishes a team with expertise in genomics, phenomics, data visualization, image analysis, machine learning, modeling, and analysis of three dimensional (3D) shapes for the common goal to bridge the environment / genotype / phenotype gap. The transformative aspect of this proposal is the novelty of the data analysis. The team has cutting-edge expertise in the mathematical and computational analysis of plant form in 3D space. However, the analysis of genome regulation hasn't changed for a decade and is stuck in 2D. The researchers propose to use their expertise on 3D shapes to elevate the standard genomic analysis to 3D, therefore opening doors to new discoveries based on the relation between genome regulation and plant form. By utilizing diverse plant species, well-characterized mutants, and machine learning, the researchers will deliver a computational algorithm to predict and model across the plant kingdom how environmental challenge regulates plant form, and which of these aspects are epigenetically inherited to the next generation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project we defined the plant’s lasting response to a high carbon dioxide (CO2) environment. We grew and examined plants at high CO2, as well as the next generation of these plants that were grown back at an ambient CO2 level. We confirmed previous data that plants grow larger at high CO2, and importantly discovered that this plant growth response is still partially present in the next generation after offspring plants were grown back at ambient CO2 levels. We determined that non-vascular plants such as mosses respond to high CO2  similarly to vascular plants, implying a conservation of these core response mechanisms throughout plant evolution. We used cutting-edge plant phenotyping and diverse plants (including crops) to examine how plant form and growth change in a high CO2 environment. We paired this phenotyping analysis with the molecular dissection of the plant gene expression, methylation and 3-dimensional (3D) organization of the DNA before, during and after growth in the high CO2 environment. This analysis was combined with the repetition of the experiment with different mutant plants, each deficient in different key genes that could be important for the persistence of the growth response to high CO2. Our data using these mutants identified the key genes necessary for the response and persistence of the accelerated growth of plants in a high CO2 environment, and our molecular genomics data identified regions of the genome with expression changes that correlate with these growth changes. 

Our 3D genome-wide analysis identified global decondensation, or “loosening” of the genome, when plants grow in a high CO2 environment. This loosening directly influences the distance between compartments or “neighborhoods” of the genome that are either active or inactive. Chromatin marks throughout the genome, such as histones and DNA methylation, correlate with changes in chromatin loops formed between small portions of the genome that interact to influence how genes are expressed. Taken together, we have developed a cutting-edge approach to analyze the 3D genome that takes advantage of multiple sources of genomics data to define how the growth of the plant and its 3D genome organization respond to a high CO2 environment.

This project continued and refined the “Mutant Millets” outreach activity, which was taught to middle and high school students across the St. Louis region. These students participated by collecting data in their classroom, training the next generation of scientists on plant and crop biology.
